220.question: How many people participated in their evaluation study of table-to-text models?

5-Table1-1.png: According to the caption, the evaluation study of table-to-text models by Tsukida and Gupta (2011) involved 10 people.</s>

222.question: By how much more does PARENT correlate with human judgements in comparison to other text generation metrics?

7-Figure3-1.png: PARENT correlates with human judgements at a value of 0.7, which is higher than any other text generation metric shown in the image.</s>
PARENT correlates with human judgements at a value of 0.7, which is higher than any other text generation metric shown in the image.</s>
6-Table2-1.png: PARENT correlates with human judgements at a level of 0.982±0.01, which is significantly higher than other text generation metrics listed in the table.</s>
PARENT correlates with human judgements at a level of 0.982±0.01, which is significantly higher than the other text generation metrics listed in the table.</s>
8-Table4-1.png: PARENT correlates with human judgements at an average of 0.846, which is 0.007 more than ROUGE, 0.006 more than CIDEr, and 0.005 more than BLEU-T.</s>
PARENT correlates with human judgements at an average of 0.846, which is 0.007 more than ROUGE, 0.006 more than CIDEr, and 0.005 more than BLEU-T.</s>

222.answer: Best proposed metric has average correlation with human judgement of 0.913 and 0.846 compared to best compared metrics result of 0.758 and 0.829 on WikiBio and WebNLG challenge.

223.question: By how much more does PARENT correlate with human judgements in comparison to other text generation metrics?

6-Table2-1.png: PARENT correlates with human judgements at a level of 0.982±0.01, which is significantly higher than other text generation metrics listed in the table.</s>
PARENT correlates with human judgements at a level of 0.982±0.01, which is significantly higher than the other text generation metrics listed in the table.</s>

223.answer: Their average correlation tops the best other model by 0.155 on WikiBio.
